big_picture_notes: Isaiah is a 66‑chapter prophetic anthology widely recognized as three major literary collections: Proto‑Isaiah (chs. 1–39, 8th‑century Assyrian crisis), Deutero‑Isaiah (chs. 40–55, 6th‑century Babylonian exile), and Trito‑Isaiah (chs. 56–66, post‑exilic restoration). The book is framed by 1:1 and unified by leitwort and motifs: 'Holy One of Israel,' blindness/deafness, covenant lawsuit (rîb), the Servant, and the promise of new creation. Genres range across oracle, narrative, woe, hymn, lament, and apocalypse. Structure is marked by inclusio, chiasm, catchwords, and historical setting shifts. For memorization, treat each small oracle or poetic unit as a scene; use clear markers (superscriptions, 'oracle' formulas, refrains, woe headings, Servant Songs) to segment.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Isaiah 1–12 introduces the whole with superscription (1:1), a sweeping covenant lawsuit (1), and thematically arranged oracles moving from judgment to remnant hope, culminating in a salvation hymn (12). Start (1:1): 'The vision of Isaiah…' End (12:6): 'Great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.' Literary Glue: 'Holy One of Israel,' remnant, movement from Assyrian judgment to Davidic/messianic hope (ch. 11) and joy (ch. 12).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Formal title: author, genre ('vision'), scope (Judah/Jerusalem), reigns—sets historical frame.

scenes.scene_name: Covenant Lawsuit: Heavens and Earth Witness
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Rîb opening 'Hear, O heavens'; metaphor of ox/donkey knowing their master vs Israel's ignorance—charged irony.
Dense parallelism ('sinful nation… people laden with iniquity'); introduces title 'Holy One of Israel.'
Head‑to‑toe medical metaphor of the body politic—total corruption and untreated wounds.
Country desolate, cities burned; isolated hut similes; remnant motif averts Sodom‑like annihilation.
Shock vocatives; rhetorical questions reject mere appearance before God—empty ritual exposed.
List of hated festivals/offerings; God 'weary' of prayers—hands full of blood links worship to injustice.
Cascade of commands defining repentance: cease evil → learn good → seek justice (orphans/widow).

scenes.scene_name: Invitation to Reason: Scarlet and Snow
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Legal invitation; total cleansing similes (scarlet/snow); two‑ways conditional of blessing/curse.
Qinah 'How' dirge contrasts former fidelity with present corruption; dross/watered wine metaphors; social injustice named.
Solemn titles introduce refining imagery ('purge dross'); restoration to 'City of Righteousness' with new name.
Antithetical parallelism: Zion redeemed by justice vs rebels destroyed—binary outcome.

scenes.scene_name: Shame of Idolatry and Unquenchable Fire
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Oaks/gardens idolatry; withered oak and waterless garden similes; strong man as tinder—unquenchable end.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Isaiah 13–23 forms a distinct collection of 'oracle/burden' (maśśā’) pronouncements concerning foreign nations (Babylon, Philistia, Moab, Damascus, Egypt, Dumah, Arabia, Jerusalem, Tyre). Start (13:1): 'The oracle concerning Babylon…' End (23:18): Tyre's wealth consecrated to the LORD. Literary Glue: repeated oracle formula (maśśā’) opening each unit.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Formal heading inaugurates the nation‑oracles sequence.
Imperatives muster Yahweh's consecrated warriors from a distant land—instrument of judgment.

scenes.scene_name: Day of the LORD: Cosmic Dread
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'Wail, for the day of the LORD is near'—psychological terror escalating to cosmic de‑creation (sun/moon/stars).

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Isaiah 40–55 shifts to the exilic setting with lyrical consolation, new‑exodus imagery, Creator‑Redeemer theology, idol polemics, and the four Servant Songs. Start (40:1): 'Comfort, comfort my people.' End (55:13): cypress/myrtle instead of thorn—everlasting sign. Literary Glue: 'comfort' refrain, Servant cycle (42:1‑9; 49:1‑7; 50:4‑11; 52:13‑53:12), and new creation/exodus motifs.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Double imperative 'Comfort'; voice of one preparing the way; glory revelation—new‑exodus highway through wilderness.

scenes.scene_name: Servant Song I: Justice to the Nations
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Behold my Servant—gentle yet steadfast, covenant to the people, light to the nations; new things declared.

scenes.scene_name: Servant Song II: Called from the Womb
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Servant as sharpened arrow; too small to restore Jacob only—light to the ends of the earth.

scenes.scene_name: Servant Song III: The Taught Tongue
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Obedient, suffering Servant; set face like flint; trust in the name of the LORD vs walking by own fire.

scenes.scene_name: Servant Song IV: Exaltation Through Suffering
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'Behold, my Servant'—pierced for our transgressions; vicarious suffering, burial with the rich; will see his offspring.
'Come, buy without money'—everlasting covenant (sure mercies of David)—core new‑exodus invitation.
Go out with joy; mountains/symbolic creation applaud; thorn → cypress, brier → myrtle—permanent memorial.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Isaiah 56–66 addresses the restored, post‑exilic community: inclusion of foreigners, denunciation of corrupt leaders, true worship/justice, Zion's glory, and the promise of 'new heavens and new earth.' Start (56:1): 'Keep justice, and do righteousness…' End (66:24): final vision of judgment outside the renewed creation. Literary Glue: concentric focus around Zion's glory (60–62) and resolution of inclusion/judgment themes.

scenes.scene_name: House of Prayer for All Peoples
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Sabbath‑keeping foreigners and eunuchs joined to the LORD; inclusio with 'my house… for all peoples.'

scenes.scene_name: True Fasting and Repairers of the Breach
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Expose faux religion; loose bonds of wickedness; then light breaks forth; ancient ruins rebuilt.
Imperatives to Zion; nations and kings drawn to dawn—beginning of Zion glory triad (60–62).

scenes.scene_name: The Anointed to Proclaim Good News
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Spirit‑anointed herald announces liberty, comfort, and planting of the LORD's oaks of righteousness.
Former things not remembered; joy in Jerusalem; wolf/lamb peace; death and curse undone in the city.
End frame: enduring seed and name; perpetual abhorrence of rebels outside the renewed creation—solemn close.
